BAHRAIN RECE© Pol .63 70/48 Events in India and Pakistan during December 1947 A. RELATIONS ‘BETWEEN THE T¥0 DOMINIONS Kashmir The Kashmir situation dominated events during the month. At the outset hopes were raised that a settlement might be possible. At a meeting at Delhi on 27th and 28th November a formula had been discussed and it had be n agreed to resume consideration of the matter at Lahore on 8th December. Thereafter however the chances of an agreement receded. Sardar Baldev Singh, Sardar Patel and Mr. Nehru all paid visits to Jammu and hoard stories of alleged atrocities committed by the Moslems. Mr. Liaqat Ali Khan visited Rawalpindi, where he lound the Azad Kashmir Government very reluctant, under the influence of their steadily improving military position in Kashmir, to consider any solution which did not provide for the establishment of an impartial administration in Kashmir and the withdrawal of the Indian troops. He also heard atrocity stories. 2. Consequently at the meeting at Lahore on 8th December a deadlock on Kashmir was reached. Both Dominions accepted the proposition that the future of the State should be settled by plebiscite as soon as the I situation permitted. But the Pakistan Government were not preparec- to appeal to the tribesmen to withdraw and the Moslem insurgents in K ac!n ' 1 to stop fighting because they knew that they would not be obeyed unless an impartial administration was to be set up as a preliminary to a plebiscite and it was clear that Moslems in the State woula be safe. The Government of India maintained their right, by virtue of Kashmir s accession to the Indian Dominion, to restore order and maintain it during the plebiscite. They were also reluctant to sacrifice Sheikh Abdullah. 3. The tension was much increased by the deterioration in the position of the Indian Forces in Kashmir. The onset of winter made / thethe Srinagar airfield unusable and rendered much aore difficult the long strung out communications of the Indian troox^s. The Moslem insurgents and raiders were increasing in numbers and their morale was high. They were able to harass the Indians right up to the gates of Jammu City, On 23rd-24th December the Indian troops were forced to withdraw from Jhangar to Naushera, with considerable casualties, and in order to relieve the situation. 4. On 21st-22nd,December the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan met at New Delhi in one more effort to reach an accommodation, but without success. It was however, agreed that the Government of India would lay the matter before the Security Council by way of complaint against the assistance given in Pakistan territory to the Moslem Forces. Ihe Pakistan Government would have preferred a joint approach to the United Nations Organisation by the two Governments with a request for their arbitration in the dispute as a whole, but the Government of India declined to'agree to this, 5, ns a preliminary step, the Government of India addressed a note to the Pakistan Government on 23rd December requesting the latter to stop participating in .the attack on Kashmir, to deny the use of Pakistan territory to the Moslem forces and all supplies and assistance to them. Failing this, the Government of India said that they would be compelled to take such action, with due regard to their rights and obligations as a member of the United Nations as seemed necessary to protect their interests and those of Kashmir. There was real danger for a few days that the Government, of India might immediately send their forces into Pakistan territory with a view of denying to the Moslem insurgents and raiders the use of facilities provided to them there and the United Kingdom Government intervened to counsel patience an the Government of India in an answer to a message informing them of the latter's intention to bring the matter before the Security Council. On 30th December, by which time the Government of India had not /received| ■ 3. received the Pakistan Government's reply to their note of 23rd Deoember, they submitted their complaint to the Security Council e ^• Finaneial Relations , At the meeting at Lahore on 8 th December referred to above agreement v/as reached betv/een the two Dominions on a number of important outstanding questions. 'Pakistan's share of the cash balances of the old undivided Government of India on the date of partition was agreed at Rs.75 crores, instead of only Rs.20 crorcs. Pakistan's share of the uncovered debt was agreed at I'/wfo, to be paid in Indian rupees in fifty annual payments of principal and interest. The value of all pensions in issue are to be capitalised and the liability shared in the ratio agreed for sharing the uncovered debt. Pakistan's share of military stores is to be one third oi the stocks held on 15 th August, In addition to the sterling assets to be transferred to Pakistan under the Pakistan (Monetary System and Reserve Bank) Order, it was agreed that Pakistan should be allowed to buy additional blocked sterling up to a limit to be ascertained by an agreed formula. Agreement was also reached on the question of the treatment of property belonging to refugees. 7» Subsequently an Indian Delegation visited Karachi for preparatory talks with the Pakistan Government on sterling balance releases. It was agreed that a system of separate accounting for foreign earnings and expenditure for the two Dominions should come on 1st January, exchange into fore 8. These agreements encouraged hope that, despite the deadlock on Kashmir reached at the same meeting, a settlement on Kashmir also might follow, but these hopes were stilled when, at the subsequent meeting at Delhi on 21st and 22nd December, the Government of India made it clear that they were for the time being not prepared to implement the agreement of 8th December so far as it related to the transfer of Rs.55 crores cash balances until the Pakistan Government ceased helping the Moslem forces in Kashmir. /junagadh5* In Junagadh the situo.tion was aore static, but sone looting and arson of Muslin property took place and the Pakistan G-overnnent alleged that life was being made intolerable for Muslins in the hope that they would leave before the plebiscite which the Government of India jjropose to hold under the auspices of either a British or Parsce judge* The leader of the Provisional Government declared that any attempt by the Nawab or his heirs to return to the throne would be qet by stiff resistance. At the end of the month the Governor General issued an ordinance vesting in the Administrator of Junagadh all the property standing in the name of the Nawab, including bank deposits and Government securities, the total amount of which was Rs.12,900,000. 10. Cor.]muna 1 Situaticn , There was little communal trouble during the mon^h. A few incidents were reported from the Punjab, and the western part of the United Provinces, There was a recrudescence of stabbing in Lelhi on 18th-19th December and a more serious outbreak of stabbing and looting at Ajmer in Rajputana. On 16th December a curfew had to be imposed in Cawnpore where an unlawful demonstration had oocurred after a speech by 'General” Mohan Singh of the Indian National Army, On the evening of the 18th December serious communal rioting broke out in Hyderabad (Sind) (as a result of the stories carried there by Moslem refugees from the affair at Ajmer), Energetic steps were at once taken to bring the situation under control and total casualties- are said to have been about 50 , of y/hich 30 were fatal, . . • B, INDIA Internal Political Situation . It was hoped that the Constituent Assembly would be able to consider the draft new Constitution in January, The Government of India accepted the principle of the formation of Provinces on a linguistic basis, but stated that its implementation must wait until the administrative machinery was more stable, A 3'g' week session of the Constituent Assembly sitting as5 . ' the Legislature considered over 20 official bills, passed the railway and general budgets and heard a number of important statements of Government policy on such subjects as Kashmir, Hyderabad, foreign affairs, refugees, de-control of foodstuffs, and the inter-Dorninion financial agreement* 12* At the end of the month the Central Committee of the Communist Party called for the establishment of n a new democratic front composed of all Left parties, progressive elements in the Congress and Muslim League, workers, peasants, students, and middle class employees*’, Dr, R,M* Lohia, a Socialist leader, characterised this move as an attempt to cover up the disruptive tactics which the Communists wished to employ. The Communist Party also proclaimed that all the political resolutions of the All India Congress Committee v/ere 'weak” and that it would need the united efforts of all progressives to halt the present trend of appeasement of vested interests on the economic front. 13* Sarat Chandra Bose in Bengal renewed his agitation against the West Bengal Security Bill and made the Bill an issue to be fought by his ney/ party, the Socialist Republican Party, which is to '*carry out the political programme of Nctaji' (Subash Chandra Bose). The Bill in question would confer special emergency powers on the Executive for the preservation of public peace. It was violently opposed also by the Hindu Mahasabha, the Trades Union Congress and the extreme Left. 14* The Hindu Mahasabha and the Sikh leader Master Tara Singh both dissociated themselves from the All Indian Congress Committee resolution on refugees and ridiculed the idea of any minorities returning to Pakistan, Hyderabad 15* A hand grenade was thrown at the Nizam on the 4th December as he was driving through Hyderabad City but he escaped unhurt. Talks between the Nizam’s Government and the State Congress Party failed. /findand a new inter in Ministry was appointed for one year under Mir Laik Al consisting of 8 Muslims and 6 Hindus, including 6 nominated officials. Sardar Patel, Deputy Prime Minister of India, publicly expressed his dissatisfaction with its composition. The State Congress Party threatened a state-wide civil disobedience movement, including the non-payment of rent, and Congress Party adherents in the Dominion of India announced their support for this. The Government of India have however advised Provincial Governments to co-operate in maintaining law and order and working the Standstill Agreement. 16. The Hyderabad Government promulgated an Ordinance banning the use of the Indian Rupee within the State for cash transactions, with a view to making the Hyderabad State Bank a central bank of issue for the State. The Indian Ministry of States informed the Nizam’s Government that they regarded this as, prima facie , a breach of the Standstill Agreement and asked for full details. Eastern States 17. On the 17th to 19th December Sardar Patel visited Cuttack and Nagpur, Following on this visit, it was announced that 39 small States of the Orissa and Chattisgarh Agencies had entered into agreements with the Dominion Government whereby, from the 1st January 1948, the administration of these States will be conducted by.the neighbouring Governments of Orissa and the Central Provinces respectively, on behalf .of the Government of India, The Rulers have been guaranteed their personal rights and privileges, their dynastic succession and a fixed privy purse, 0 Fnal j^ajrs , Palestine continued to receive a great deal of publicity, and sympathy for the Arabs was whole-hearted, finding expression in criticism of the United States, of U.N.O, for its partition decision, and of the U.S.SJU for its desire to fish in troubled waters. Condemnation of the South African Government's policy towards Indians in that country was very bitter, end the voteon the natter in the United Nations Assembly was considered a moral victory for India, although a two-thirds majority ms not obtained* 19* The opening of Ceylon's Dominion Parliament was greeted with optimism, but the status of Indians in Ceylon is to be taken up at the earliest opportunity. 20. Pandit Nehru made a statement in the Legislature on India’s foreign policy, in the course of which he emphasised the necessity for India to avoid big power entanglements. 21. Food policy . On 10th December a new food policy was announced by the Government of India, amounting to a progressive de-control of food grains. Rationing and controlled prices will disappear 'as soon as may be feasible” but de-control is to be backed by a main reserve- central stock of 500 thousand tons of imported food grains. The skeleton of the food control organisation is to be retained in case this experiment should prove a failure, 22. Industries Conference . At an Industries Conference held in Delhi under the auspices of the Government of India, emphasis v/as laid on the grave economic condition of the country arising in large measure / from the decline in industrial production caused by transport difficulties, labour troubles and shortages of raw materials. 23. Shipping . The Government of India’s proposals for the expansion of the mercantile marine are reported to have been accepted with certain reservations by the Indian Shipping Companies. 24. Import Control . Owing to continued shortage of foreign exchange, the main features of the present import control restrictions are to continue during January to June 1948, In addition open general licences for imports of certaLa goods from the sterling area have been cancelled and import licences for them are now required* £1 PAKISTAN 25* Internal Political Situation , At the end of the month the Pakistan Cabinet was enlarged by the inclusion of Sir Mahommad /ZafrullahZafrullah Khan as Foreign Minister. Mr. Liaqat Ali Khan remains Prime Minister and retains the Defence portfolio. 26. Cabinet changes were rumoured in the Provinces. In the West runjab, the Government had to meet with much criticism, especially on account ci the conditions in refugee camps there. In East Bengal, indignation arising from a local breakdown of food rationing at Dacca tendca to centre on the Prime Minister, as being responsible for the selection of the Cabinet. Rumours were current that a Cabinet might be iormea under his mercurial opponent Mr. Fazlul KaV. League. Mr, H.S. Suhrawardy continued his campaign for the abolition of the existing Muslim League and its replacement in Pakistan by a National League open to members of all communities. He was also reported to have welcomed Mr. Gandhi’s suggestion that Muslims in India should join the Congress, North West Frontier 2d, On 27th December the withdrawal of Pakistan troops from Waairistan was completed, 'Dawn” commented - perhaps optimistically - 'the tribesmen have now voluntarily taken it upon themselves to defend the frontier of Pakistan'. In Baluchistan a scheme was put forward tor an amalgamation of the area with the province of Sind, Quetta being maae the permanent capital for the now Province, iu 1 ours » As in India, the Palestine question attracted a great deal of attention and there was much talk of pan-Islamism and the solidarity of the Muslim countries. including Pakistan, with the Arab cause. 30, Sardar Najibullah Khan, the special representative of the King Afghanistan reached Karachi for negotiations for the placing of Pakistan-wfghan relations on a formal basis. He expressed the desire of the Afghan Government for co-operation and gave an assurance that fundamental interests of the two countries could never conflict, Mr, Jinnah’s reply was confined to the hope that /mattersAm © 9. natters requiring iLinediate attention would soon be adjusted. Afghanistan appears to have rather far reaching ideas as to the status of the North West Frontier Province. il. The Pakistan press, ccnnenting on the Cabinet crisis in Iran, sympathised with the difficulties, of a 'small country' in the face of insistent demands from a powerful neighbour, j2 ‘ Conference . A meeting in Karachi called by the Pakistan Government set up machinery to consider measures for the development of industries e.g. cotton textiles and irrigation and hyaro-electric schemes. The Minister of Commerce outlined the extent to which the Government proposed to own or control industry and suggested participation of foreign capital, management and technical services in industrial projects. mPl. 0 :-- Normally, Pakistan has a surplus of food; but, consequent upon the deterioration of the cold-weather crop in the West Punjab and the influx of refugees from India this surplus will ' not arise this year. Sven the surplus rice of West Punjab will be inadequate to meet the deficit in Sast Bengal, a Conference of representatives of India and Pakistan is to discuss outstanding food commitments between, the two Dominions in New Delhi early in January. Railway Rates. Increases of 22% in the .rates for goods and passengers, of 20^ for parcels and luggage, and of 8^ for coal were announced to take effect from the 1st January, 1948. Certain commodities hitherto exempt from earlier increases in rates will continue to be exempt. The increases are attributed to the difficulty of ootaining-coal- and the higher costs of operation. The railways have operated'at a heavy loss since August 13th. V:. Air Transport. Air Transport is tq be left for the present to private enterprise but will be regulated by the State. The problem is partly one of financing the ginning factories, and although this has been partly met by the institution of a Pakistan Finance Corporation, the disruption of normal commercial and banking- channels due to the exodus of the Hindus, the shortage of coal and the loss of Hindu and Sikh technicians remain formidable difficulties. 37* Jute . mods.abstract: The file contains a report, with covering correspondence, entitled Events in India and Pakistan during December 1947. The report was produced by the Government of India following the partition of the country. The author is not known.The report is divided into three sections, the first relating to relations between the two dominions and the second and third relating to the internal situation of India and Pakistan, respectively.
